1959
COELENTERATES.
Introduction
.While working with coelenterates in the laboratory it is essential
to remember that the hydroids are very sensitive to environmental con-
ditions. They do not survive well in the laboratory even in aquaria
of running water. When removed to fingerbowls, the individuals are
apt to die unless kept below room temperature. When working
with the stems of hydroids, use few stems in large volumes of water,
and change the water frequently. Do not crowd either the adult stems
or the eggs and embryos. It is not"g55d to spoil experiments lasting
l2-24 hours by being careless about crowding the material.
In general it is advisable to select a goodsized colony, examine
it under low power to find the gonads, and to clip off the branches
containing the best material. These can be rinsed in running sea
water and further sorted and separated.

The ability of the hydrozoa to regenerate and to reproduce by
budding has been famous 200 years. iubularia is favorable material
as an example because of its size and abundance. 1
Temperature is a very important limiting factor to these animals.
lney drop off their hydranths in midsummer when the water warms above
Qi degrees C, and remain dormant until the water cools, and then put
out new ones (Moore Regeneration never takes place at tmepera~
tures above 250 C. so the experimental material must be kept in finger~
bowls in running sea water.
Qiafaie of T2E@n??3ti9Qri@ E?9Ximal 333 disiel ha1V@5~
With sharp scissors cut a number of individuals from the colony
at their points of attachment, selecting those which measure 50 mm.
vr so in length. From these, cut off the hydranths, each with a
millimeter of stem (to get rid of the base of the hydranth, which is
somewhat retarded in its regeneration). Take 20 beheaded stalks of
uniform size and cut them each into equal halves, putting the distal
(hydranth) halves in one fingerbowl of sea water and the proxima
halves in another. (Avoid pinching or damaging them in transfer .
Cover the fingerbowls and place them in the sink where they will be
kept cool by the running sea water. Change the water several times a
day.
Usually l8-24 hours after cutting, the primordium of the oral and
basal tentacles can be seen thru the perisarc. Observe that the hy~
dranth differenetiates in situ and not as an outgrowth. See the cir-
culation in the stem. After 50 hours, take freqrnt observations and
record the time of emergence of the new hydranths in both lots. After
60 hours, compare the rates of regeneration of distal and proximal 
halves. Any indication of an axial gradient of regeneration-rate?
(Barth i
